awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites - Type I: George Washington University I-Corps Site for Innovation and Entrepreneurship
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from George Washington University, creates an I-Corps Site at this institution. NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

The George Washington University Office of Innovation and Entrepreneurship (OI&E) collaborates with multiple units on campus to dramatically increase student and faculty teams from the STEM disciplines in OI&E innovation and commercialization activities. There is a strong network of mentors who are key in this process. OI&E developed multiple versions of the Lean Startup curriculum and will continue to do so to meet the special needs of undergraduate students, women, minorities, and veterans in the STEM disciplines. OI&E is also creating courseware in support of experienced entrepreneurs, investors, and business professionals who have not yet learned to apply lean startup methods. Doing so brings value to an entire startup ecosystem that is important to startup success. The broader impacts include spreading entrepreneurial thinking among the faculty, developing a well-trained cadre of mentors and adding to the diversity of the pool of mentors, especially women and veterans. These are important goals in entrepreneurship and commercialization and the project is specific about how this Site will advance these broader impacts.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The George Washington I-Corps Site for Innovation was a five-year award designed to foster, grow, and nurture innovation ecosystems regionally and nationally. Through this award, InnovateGW was established as a collaboration between the GW Office of Innovation and Entrepreneurship (GWOIE) and both the GW School of Engineering and Applied Science (SEAS) and the GW Office of the Vice Provost for Research (OVPR). The project recruited student and faculty teams from the STEM disciplines into GWOIE innovation and entrepreneurship activities and moved the teams and their technologies into multiple commercialization paths.  Both SEAS and OVPR held large annual research exhibitions that engaged hundreds of technology teams, many of whom were good candidates for InnovateGW. Potential teams were also recruited from the GW New Venture Competition (NVC) and the GW Summer Startup Accelerator, both run by GWOIE, as well as through general outreach activities to GW students and faculty.  We also developed a partnership with the Virginia Innovation Commercialization Assistance Program (ICAP). ICAP is a partnership between GW I-Corps, the Virginia SBDC network, and the Virginia Innovation Partnership Corporation (VIPC). Besides serving as GW and GMU?s Regional I-Corps programs, the program serves, through state funding, a network of 14 universities, five regional business accelerators, and 11 state and regional economic development agencies and over 100 referring organizations.

In the second half of 2020, with funding from an NSF I-Corps Site Supplemental Grant, we introduced the Introduction to Lean Innovation workshop as a key team recruitment program for I-Corps, supplementing our classroom visits and customer discovery workshop classroom modules.

The Introduction to Lean Innovation workshop is a 2-hour session that introduces the basic concepts of Lean Innovation and I-Corps. Potential innovators from all GW schools and degree pursuits are welcome, including undergrad students, masters, PhD students, postdocs, faculty, and staff. 

After completing the introductory workshop, participants who wanted to continue with InnovateGW were able to opt-in to our regular Regional Short Course (or Boot Camp) programs. This customer discovery training is supported by team-aligned adjunct instructors (?mentors?) and staff from GWOIE. Progressive ?lessons learned? sessions are conducted after each week of

Upon completion of a Boot Camp, became eligible for the NSF I-Corps National Teams program if the Director of I-Corps at GW determined they met the qualifications. Adjuncts and GWOIE staff also continued to work with teams to pursue other relevant commercialization options such as licensing, startup planning, or SBIR applications.

Through the duration of the award, $107,402 was provided to teams through Participant Support funding. Teams were only able to access Participant Support funding after conducting twenty interviews through the two-week Boot Camp. Participant Support funding was only able to be used toward expenses to conduct additional customer discovery or expenses related to prototype building.

In 2020, we greatly expanded our outreach to black, Latino, Asian, and women students at GW. With additional funding provided by the NSF I-Corps Site Supplemental grant, we were able to recruit a more diverse pipeline for all our student entrepreneurship programs -- and specifically the InnovateGW program -- with the ultimate goal of sending more diverse teams to the NSF I-Corps National Teams Program. We created a list of student leaders, faculty connectors, research directors, and others at the university who have a high level of engagement with our multicultural communities. This work was done in collaboration with the GW Diversity and Inclusion office, which was able to point us to the virtual sites of practice where many students and faculty of color go for their information and events.

We also developed best practices for setting individual meetings with diverse student organizations, and built unique, tailored emails to them for recruitment. We were able to target and develop a communications strategy that included being on newsletters throughout the university, especially those focused on underrepresented groups in STEM.

In 2021, we started the Entrepreneur Development Network of DC, in partnership with Howard University, funded through a grant from Wells Fargo Foundation and PEPCO. This program was designed to increase our outreach to underserved communities and other DC universities, such as Georgetown, American, and Catholic universities. This program was modeled after our GW I-Corps program and our Virginia ICAP partnership, and has served over 100 teams in a little over a year.

GW's involvement with NSF I-Corps didn't end at the end of this Site award. In 2021, GW, along with several other institutions, was awarded a five-year I-Corps Hub grant that will end in 2027. For more information on GWOIE, visit innovation.gwu.edu.


Last Modified: 06/02/2022
Modified by: Robert J Smith
